post_text:
Math Movement is in full swing. This week students performed a variety of activities for one minute. Each activity was done twice. Students then compared the number of times they completed activities using less than, greater than and equal to symbols. Students are also participating in Mask Movement Breaks on Thursdays by learning line dance routines taught by Mr. E. During the first week of school, students and staff performed the Electric Slide.
http://rsu18messenger.com/2020/09/10/math-movement-at-wes/

RSU 18 schools engaged in some pretty great out of the box thinking to welcome students back to this rather unusual school year. Small group outdoor gatherings, beep and greets, and online video tours gave students a way to meet their teachers and get familiar with their new school or classroom. Several schools even created virtual open houses that they sent out to parents and posted to their websites. [ 74 more words ]

On Thursday, August 27, Atwood Primary School teamed with Williams Elementary to host a Beep and Greet for all of our school families. The children, along with their families, remained in their cars and safely paraded through the Atwood Playground and past Williams where they were greeted with music and all of their teachers holding signs welcoming them into the 2020-21 school year!

post_text:
RSU 18 chorus classes aren't letting social distancing rules stop them from raising their voices in song. Campuses across the district have been filled with music as students get out into the beautiful fall weather to put the required 14 feet of distance between them while they practice their songs.
#WeAreRSU18

The first ShineOnCass project of the year happened across RSU18 schools on the first day of school, which would have been Cassidy Charette‚Äôs 23rd birthday. Students decorated tags that had the message ‚ÄúKindness if free, sprinkle it everywhere‚Äù on it, that were then put under staff‚Äôs windshield wipers. The first day of school after 6 months of being closed for a pandemic is a whole new level of crazy. [ 57 more words ]

post_text:
A message from our transportation department:
We had some issues with clothing being bleached out from our sanitation efforts. Although we were using a product issued by the district, it is apparent the product was over-applied. Beginning today, we re-trained all of the driver's how to properly clean and sanitize the seats. The product build-up is in the process of being washed off, with the majority of the buses already cleaned. We are taking every precaution to keep our children safe during their transportation to and from school. Thank you for your patience as we all work through this challenge.
text:
A message from our transportation department:
We had some issues with clothing being bleached out from our sanitation efforts. Although we were using a product issued by the district, it is apparent the product was over-applied. Beginning today, we re-trained all of the driver's how to properly clean and sanitize the seats. The product build-up is in the process of being washed off, with the majority of the buses already cleaned. We are taking every precaution to keep our children safe during their transportation to and from school. Thank you for your patience as we all work through this challenge.

post_text:
We‚Äôre so excited to announce that RSU 18 has received a $25 000 grant from the Albertsons Companies Foundation Nourishing Neighbors Summer Meals Program. These funds support our RSU 18 Summer Meals Program under the direction of Barbara Bonnell, RSU 18 School Nutrition Director. This gift comes just in time because RSU 18 and other organizations that fight food insecurity are experiencing a dramatic increase in requests for assistance. Our thanks to Albertson Companies Foundation and our local Shaws store. And, of course, thank you for your continued support during this very challenging time!
http://rsu18messenger.com/2020/08/12/nourishing-neighbors-summer-meals-grant/

shared_text:
Vanessa Doyon shared a post to the group: James H Bean PTO.
August 11 at 11:56 AM ¬∑

Football Update for RSU 18 Munchkins

Messalonskee Youth Football
August 10 at 3:45 PM ¬∑

Hey all! Just an update that we still plan on having a season, but not what we tradionally do. We will most likely be offering a flag footall program of some sort. The Kennebec Valley Youth Football league is meeting this week to discuss this and more updates are to come when we know more. The season would not start for our program until beginning of September after labor day. We have already been informed that Augusta is not going to be playing football outside of their community this year. Before any official decision is made, our program will still need to consult with the high school coach, athletic directors, Superintendent, oakland rec etc to make the best informed decision. We still need permission to use facilities for practice, games and a lot of other considerations that are currently being evaluated. Thank you all so much for your patience as we will know a lot more in the coming week. Please share, and GO EAGLES!

This Sunday is Maine Open Farm Day! Like many events this year, they have gone virtual which means you can check out many different farms across the state without the long drive.

In fact, Real Maine is launching a whole week of virtual farm days which will run from Sunday, July 26th through Friday, July 31st. RSVP to the event to join them online and explore different aspects of Maine agriculture.

For more information on this year's virtual Open Farm Day and ways to support your local farms, go tohttps://www.getrealmaine.com/real-maine-news/open-farm-day-is-online-summer-2020/

As a way to come together during these troubling times, 17,572 singers from 129 countries formed a virtual chorus to perform Eric Whitacre's "Sing Gently".

Raising their voices with this amazing group, we find RSU 18's very own Kevin and Pamela Rhein as well as their oldest daughter, Nia Passmore. Please take a moment to enjoy this amazingly beautiful and inspiring video.

"May we stand together, always.
May our voice be strong.
May we hear the singing and
May we always sing along."

post_text:
Hello all! I am happy to report that MMS yearbooks are finally here and ready to go home!

You can come in to MMS on Wednesday, July 1st. They will be available to be picked up from 7:30-11:30AM and 2:00-6:00PM at MMS.

Most of the yearbooks have already been pre-ordered but there are 22 yearbooks that can be purchased first come first serve at MMS. Please do not call and try to reserve a yearbook. Go to MMS as close to 7:30AM as possible. The cost is $22 and can be paid by cash or a check made out to Messalonskee Middle School.

If you have any questions, email Blair Weatherbie at bweatherbie@rsu18.org, or call the office at 465-2167.

Thank you!

Mark Hatch

PUBLIC NOTICE

REGIONAL SCHOOL UNIT NO. 18

NOTICE OF REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS
FOR SNOW REMOVAL AND SANDING SERVICES

PUBLIC NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that Regional School Unit No. 18 (RSU 18) located in Oakland, Maine is seeking proposals for snow removal and sanding services for the 2020-21 and 2021-22 school years at the following locations:

‚óè RSU 18 Atwood Elementary School/Central Office area
‚óè RSU 18 Messalonskee High School/Messalonskee Middle School/Williams Elementary
School area
‚óè RSU 18 Transportation/Maintenance/Biomass Plant area

Please prepare a separate sealed bid proposal for each plowing area you are submitting proposal(s) for. Proposal(s) must be received by 1:00 pm on Monday, July 20, 2020.
Refer to RSU 18‚Äôs Request for Proposal (RFP) for additional information and respond as requested. RFP‚Äôs are available at the RSU 18 Office of the Superintendent, 41 Heath St.,
Oakland, ME 04963 from 8:00 AM - 3:00 PM Monday through Friday (207 465-7384) or from the district‚Äôs website www.rsu18.org.

The BCS 5th-grade promotion was amazing! We had a superb staff turnout and all of the 5th-grade students came!

The parade was led by a fire truck and supported by state troopers. Each 5th-grade student received a bag filled with goodies and a positive message and letter from Mrs. Bacon. Staff lined the walkways and waved red, white, and blue streamers as the students drove through.

It really was a great time.

Written by Jamie Wade, BCS School Counselor

Written by Jenna Zemrak Back in February, two hundred Atlantic salmon eggs arrived at Belgrade Central School. Small, round, salmon-colored blobs sat in the bottom of a thermos and 30 second- graders were amazed at what they saw. The Maine Council of the Atlantic Salmon Federation sponsors this school-based program in order to help the Atlantic Salmon population, which is endangered and only found in the wild in our Maine rivers. [ 265 more words ]
http://rsu18messenger.com/2020/06/10/fish-friends-atlantic-salmon-fish-release-with-bcs-second-graders/

Julia Hanauer-Milne organized a virtual field trip to Acadia for her 3rd through 5th graders at BCS, JHB, and WES on May 12th. Acadia Ranger Lisa Girardin showed kids how different animals in the intertidal zone, such as barnacles, sea stars, and crabs, are adapted to life in their environment. She also discussed research that scientists are conducting to record populations and conditions to understand how the Gulf of Maine is changing. [ 49 more words ]

MMS Team Katahdin teacher Lindsay Mahoney has been named Kennebec County Teacher of the Year! The formal announcement was made today during a ceremony hosted on Zoom and live-streamed on the Maine Department of Education Facebook page. Ms. Mahoney teaches Math and Science to 6th through 8th-grade students at Messalonkee Middle School and was nominated by her colleague Hope Herrick. She holds degrees from the University of Maine and the University of Maine at Farmington. [ 217 more words ]

Local couple Crystal and James Douglas recently made a $500 donation to RSU 18 to help get books into the hands of elementary students in need during the school closure. On Monday, April 27th, Maine Public will be launching The Learning Space, a new project developed in conjunction with the Maine Department of Education and Educate Maine. Teachers from across the state have developed and recorded 1/2 hour video lessons for grades 3 through 5 which will be offered as an educational resource on Maine Public Television. "I think the Learning Space is going to be an awesome support for students across the state," said RSU 18 Instructional Coach, Shelly Moody. [ 58 more words ]
http://rsu18messenger.com/2020/04/26/maine-public-launches-the-learning-space-on-monday/

Our nutrition program will be open during April vacation with a few small changes. Meal sites will not be open on Monday as it is a holiday. During the week of vacation, our delivery days will switch to Tuesday and Friday. Please know that the Alfond Youth Center will also be continuing their meal plan through April vacation. Curbside service will continue to be available from 4:30-5:30 in all four locations.
http://rsu18messenger.com/2020/04/13/nutrition-program-during-april-vacation/

Due to the storm and the power outages our nutrition program will be delayed today. Our meal sites will be open from 11:00 to 1:00.

Please help us spread the word on this so our students get food for the weekend.

And many thanks to our amazing nutrition staff for your dedication.

Carl

post_text:
One of the most popular events held at the high school library is the Lunchtime Music Series sponsored by the MHS Tri-M Music Honor Society. Once a month, all students are invited to perform before the school community in an open mic show. It is a standing room only event. Audience members are entertained by a wide variety of vocal and instrumental performances including but not limited to solos, brass combos, guitar melodies, choral groups, and jazz ensembles. [ 260 more words ]
http://rsu18messenger.com/2020/04/09/the-music-never-stopped-lunchtime-music-series-moves-to-zoom/

We are definitely living through a time that calls for us to pay a bit more attention to our mental and emotional wellbeing. To that end, district social worker KC Beaupain has created a Facebook page called The Virtual Zen Den. Mrs. Beaupain is a Licensed Clinical Social Worker and yoga teacher and she uses this page to provide children (and adults) with different mindfulness activities that can help support wellbeing. [ 27 more words ]

Mrs. Veilleux challenged her 4th-grade WES class to a STEM activity during remote learning time. Students were asked to build a roller coaster. There were no guidelines or parameters, just exploration and building. They made some amazing structures! The next day they worked on IXL science skills that reinforced the learning targets of force and motion that students explored while creating their roller coasters.

Atwood and Williams PE teacher Patrick Engleright has started holding morning workouts through Zoom three times a week. On Monday, Wednesday, and Friday mornings at 9:00, Mr. Engleright welcomes students, takes a few minutes to check-in and connect, then shares his screen and does a specifically selected workout video with them. This not only helps students get moving in the morning, but it also gives them a chance to see friends and any teachers who join in and helps them feel more connected with their school community. [ 31 more words ]

We are leveraging that signal to provide absolutely free connectivity to everyone in our communities. [ 83 more words ]

We are working to perform an upgrade to our phone system that will help our employees work remotely. This upgrade will add features giving us the ability to sign into a ‚Äúsoft phone‚Äù so people working from home can receive in-district calls, or calls routed through our automated attendant. Phase one of the upgrade is scheduled for tomorrow, Wednesday, March 25th. The district phones will be down for 1-2 hours to complete this step. Another update will be performed next week for phase two.

shared_text:
Vanessa Doyon‚ÄéJames H Bean PTO
March 12 at 1:55 PM ¬∑

As we have all followed the news ‚Ä¶ the recent concerns and outbreak with the Coronavirus - We have told that we are to CANCEL the VIP DANCE.

At this time we do not plan to reschedule this event.

We want to ensure that was a decision was not made for any reason BUT protection of our munchkins and community. This is a directive from the Superintendents Office, which was directed to cancel non-essential gatherings of folks per the state government.

We will reimburse for the event. We ask that you are patient with us, we are hopes to get all the forms and monies back to the families by the end of next week.

I understand that folks have many different opinions regarding this outbreak. I ask that you do not have heated debates over this cancellation of event on our PTO page.

We thank each and everyone of you whom planned to attend this event.

We ask that you keep your eyes on our next event. We have moved our Bounce Into Spring Party to May 1st, 2020. More details will be released to this event soon - stay tuned.

#jhbpto #stayhealthy #projectplayground #rsu18

Students in Miss Whitlock's third grade at CPS have been learning about the states of matter. They started their learning with a Mystery Science lesson that involved a candy melt. Students needed to figure out what candy would be good to send to their friend at camp without it melting. They discussed whether certain candies had properties that would make them a good contender to send or if this candy was too meltable.

The Belgrade Kindergarten students have been busy researching, learning and sharing information about 2 Maine animals. Ms. Arsenault‚Äôs class became experts about Maine Black Bears and Miss. Polk‚Äôs class learned all about Moose. The children used Lucy Calkins‚Äô approach to writing non-fiction stories using facts they learned, diagrams and the writing process to create informational books. It only made sense for each expert to share their knowledge, so the children found a partner in another classroom to teach a friend what they had learned. The children were excited to share what they knew! written by Rachel Arsenault

Senior Molly Glueck and Alumni Julia Cooke performed together in the ACDA All Eastern Broadway Musical Theater Repertoire Choir at the Kodak Hall of the Eastman Theater in Rochester NY in early March. They are pictured above with their director Maestro Rob Fisher and accompanist Ian Axness on performance day. Molly stated, ‚Äú It was an excellent musical experience. Students in grades 3-5 at Williams Elementary learned about plant varieties and parts during a session with Maine Agriculture in the classroom. Presenters read a book, taught students a movement to remember the six parts of a plant, and then students were invited to look for different varieties of greens in a spring mix. The best part was that students were able to identify and taste test the different varieties in their laboratories!

For the past five years, WES has celebrated our love for reading during the month of March with a school-wide March Madness tournament. All classrooms will read 16 nonfiction picture books on a wide variety of topics including inventors, space, animals, athletes, and historic events. Each week students will vote for their favorite books to move to the Elite 8, the Final 4 and eventually our book championship on April 8th! [ 176 more words ]

Thought to be one of the last plays that Shakespeare wrote alone, Tempest is a magical concoction of comedy, fantasy, romance, and revenge. Messalonskee Middle School has kicked off their School-Wide read this year. We are reading The Benefits of Being an Octopus by Ann Braden. As a school, we are reading the book with all students during our advisory period. Students and teachers are having some great conversations around the tough issues the book presents. Zoe, the main character shares her story of managing her life which involves watching her three younger siblings after school, picking up the pieces when her mother is unable to meet all of the children‚Äôs needs, and finding ways to fly under the radar at school. [ 177 more words ]

APP.LIFECHANGEROFTHEYEAR.COM
Dan Wilson

LifeChanger of the Year
February 25 at 1:01 PM ¬∑

Every day, Dan Wilson arrives before his scheduled time to make sure his school is ready for the teachers and students. If the roads are icy in the early morning, he'll send out an email to the staff with a warning to drive carefully on the roads. Before every holiday, he'll out an email wishing everyone a wonderful vacation. His ability to think of others is second nature, and it's what makes him a LifeChanger in RSU 18!

post_text:
Fifth-grade students from China Middle School and Vassalboro Community School are continuing the work started two years ago by fellow students helping with the revegetation project at the Masse Dam Site in Vassalboro. They are learning the connections between alewives, native plants and the restoration of Maine waterways back to their original state. The restoration of Maine waterways, also known as the Alewife Restoration Initiative, will allow river herring, an anadromous fish, to return to freshwater to spawn. [ 223 more words ]
http://rsu18messenger.com/2020/02/24/cms-students-helping-to-restore-waterways/

January was Wellness Month for staff at JHB. Each week focused on a different aspect of making choices toward a healthy and fulfilling life. There were four weekly health-based challenges: hydration, exercise, mindfulness and sleep. Each Friday, a wellness newsletter was sent to staff informing them of the weekly challenge. Additionally, all staff members were invited to a ‚ÄúMove-It Monday‚Äù activity which included creating an indoor walking route, a yoga class led by school social worker KC Beaupain, a zumba class led by Krystal Blaisdell, and a paint afternoon led by art teacher Heidi Roberts. Ms. Frankenfield & Ms. Chamberlain‚Äôs ELA classes held the first CMS Living Wax Museum on December 6th. Over 100 5-7th grade students turned the CMS Library into their very own wax museum. Family and friends were invited to see their students transform into a variety of famous people. Students worked hard to engage in research, craft a monologue, and design and create a backdrop as well as a costume.

Williams Elementary students participated in the Greg Tang math challenge over the December Break. Students participated in both online and paper-based math practice that involved a wide variety of concepts, games, Equato, word searches, and Numtanga. The math challenge started on December 16 and will run through January 9. Students will receive a certificate of completion and be entered into a drawing for some cool prizes.

The Kindergartners at James H. Bean were able to participate in Chewonki‚Äôs Owls of Maine Traveling Exhibit. Three live owls are the highlights of this program which introduced our students to the owls native to Maine and New England. The presentation begins with slides and sounds of different types of owls. Students learn the identifying characteristics and calls of each owl, then, using talons, wings, and skulls, we explore the adaptations of these silent nocturnal hunters. [ 36 more words ]

It‚Äôs a New Year and a new round of Gratitude Grants is ready to be put into action. A few weeks before Thanksgiving, RSU 18‚Äôs Lifestyles Team challenged district administrators to submit a 1-page Gratitude Grant proposal outlining how they would use a $200 grant to teach students the values of being gracious, thankful, and giving. Since this year‚Äôs theme ties in with the upcoming 2020 Tokyo Olympics, a connection to the Olympic values of respect, friendship, and excellence was also strongly encouraged. [ 213 more words ]

Each month at China Primary students from every classroom are chosen by their teacher to receive a student of the month award. There are three different awards to be given, one for a student who shows kindness, one for students who try their best or show ‚Äúgrit‚Äù and an award for being responsible. The recipients receive their award during a monthly assembly and are recognized for being role models in each of these areas. In addition to students, staff members who exemplify these behaviors are presented with an award and applauded by students and staff.
http://rsu18messenger.com/2019/12/31/celebrating-different-kinds-of-success-at-cps/

Every year, Messalonskee Middle School celebrates the winter season with Winter Wonderland. For over twenty years, the week before break, students at Messalonskee Middle create lots of wonderful holiday books, obstacle courses, dance/movement activities, face painting, ornaments (wooden), bake cookies for decorating, and decorate halls and rooms. Our band and chorus play holiday music, too! For the past two years, we have added a competition to create a photo frame for the buddy photo open to our seventh and eighth graders. [ 527 more words ]

I am happy to announce that Williams Elementary School has been awarded a $416 Let‚Äôs Go! Mini-Grant from Northern Light Inland Hospital to support our school‚Äôs Let‚Äôs Go! Work. At Williams, we will be creating a sensory path with decals in our school hallways for all grade levels. This sensory path will give students an opportunity to release energy and tension by traveling through a series of physical movements like hopping, skipping, balancing, jumping and stretching while improving their ability to learn.
